metadata.title: Experimental study of the effect of various surfactants on surface sediment and pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of silica/DI water nano-fluid

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Powder Technology
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /powtec
Experimental study of the effect of various surfactants on surface sediment and pool boiling heat transfer coefficient of silica/DI water nano-fluid
Zhe Tian a,b, Sasan Etedali c, Masoud Afrand c, Ali Abdollahi c, Marjan Goodarzi d,⁎ a School of Engineering, Ocean University of China, Qingdao 266100, China b Key Laboratory of Fluid Power and Intelligent Electro-Hydraulic Control (Fuzhou University), Fujian Province University, Fuzhou 350108, China c Department of Mechanical Engineering, Najafabad Branch, Islamic Azad University, Najafabad, Iran d Sustainable Management of Natural Resources and Environment Research Group, Faculty of Environment and Labour Safety, Ton Duc Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: marjan.goodarzi@tdtu.edu.vn (M. Goo
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.powtec.2019.08.049 0032-5910/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 15 March 2019 Received in revised form 19 July 2019 Accepted 20 August 2019 Available online 21 August 2019
In this experimental study, the pool boiling heat transfer of silica DI water nano-fluid with three various surfactants on the surface of copper heaters at different concentrations at atmospheric pressure has been investigated experimentally. The nano-fluid has been synthesized by a two-step process and has suitable stability. The results show that the boiling heat transfer of surfactant-DI water is higher than that of DIwater. Moreover, surfactant-DI water has a higher heat transfer coefficient than silica-surfactant-DI water nano-fluid. For nano-fluidswith fewer concentrations than 0.5% vol., the boiling heat transfer coefficient for silica-DI water for all surfactants is larger than that of DI water. The boiling heat transfer coefficient of the nano-fluids with anionic surfactant (SDS) is greater than cationic surfactant (CTAB) and cationic is larger than nonionic surfactant (PS20). Results also indicated that surface roughness and sediment are depends on surfactant type due to boiling of the nano-fluid.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. Keywords: Pool boiling Surface sediment SiO2/DI water nano-fluid Surfactant Heat transfer coefficient

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Boiling heat transfer (BHT) is extensively used in thermal engineering. Many researchers in recent years have been focusing on engineering applications to develop the science of boiling heat transfer. Nano-fluids are compounds of nano-particles with sizes smaller than 100 nm in base-fluid [1,2]. Adding nano-particles is one of the inactive methods to increase boiling heat transfer. Many studies have been done on nano-fluid boiling heat transfer [3–16].
Previous research has shown that for the results of the boiling heat transfer coefficient (BHTC), the results of the nano-particle increase are not the same. Some researchers have reported their BHTC unchanged, while some reported a decrease in BHTC and other reports are associated with increasing heat transfer coefficient (HTC) [5]. In order to achieve the same results in increasing or decreasing the BHTC, further study is needed on effective parameters on boiling properties of nano-fluid, including surface geometry and topology. Considering that research on the variation of the boiling surface and the formation of sediment on it due to the boiling heat transfer is very important, below are some of the important researches in this field.
Sarafraz et al. [17] studied the effect of nano-particle size on the sediment and BHTC of the aluminum oxide/water nano-fluid. They
darzi).
observed thatwith a reduction in the size of the nano-particles and a decrease in sediment, BHTC increases. They reported the reasons for the sediment depending on the size of the nano-particles and the basic properties of the heater surface. Finally, the change in the density of the active nucleation sites and the change in the boiling thermal resistance caused by the sediments, justified the change in HTC.
Ahmad and Hamed [18] investigated the effect of aluminum oxide/ water nano-fluid deposition on BHTC of the nano-fluid in a laboratory. Theyreportedtheconcentrationparameterofnano-fluidinitsboilingprocess very important. They also found that the sediment is completely dependent on the concentration of nano-particles. They also observed that, for aluminumoxide/water nano-fluid at low concentrations (0.01% vol.), theeffectofsedimentisverylowandHTCincreases,whileforhighconcentrations the sediment has increased and the heat transfer is reduced.
Das et al. [19,20] investigated BHTC of aluminum oxide/water nanofluid (with concentrations of 4–16% byweight) on a horizontal cylindrical surface with a roughness of 0.37–0.45 μm (with a roughness size larger than that of nano-particles). The results show that the sediment of nano-particles on the surface causes the cavities to fill up the holes and reduce heat transfer. In addition, BHTC decreases with increasing concentrations.
The pool boiling heat transfer of suspensions was reported by Kim et al. [21] for aluminum nano-particles. A wire with made of stainless steel a diameter of 0.381 mm and a length of 120 mm has been used as a thermal heater. The results show that during the nucleate boiling,
some nano-particles are deposited on the surface of the heater.With increasing surface wettability, the probability of filling the holes with nano-fluid increases, the density of nuclear sites decreases and BHTC decreases.
Salimpour et al. [22] studied the sediment formation on the surface of a coarse and smooth copper heater due to the pool boiling heat transfer process of DIwater/ iron oxide nano-fluid. The findings revealed that the effect of surface deposition is more dependent on great concentrations of nano-fluid.Moreover, results on the rough surface after the boiling test showed that, in low heat flux, the boiling heat transfer decreased, while it increased in high heat flux. For a smooth surface, the boiling heat transfer of the nano-fluid increases in low heat flow, while does not change in high heat flux. Therefore, for smooth surfaces with lowheatflux and high roughness surfaceswith high heat flux, heat transfer is enhanced by depositing on the surface.
Liu and Liao [23] investigated nano-fluid boiling with a base-fluid of water and alcohol (C2H5OH) andwith SiO2 and CuO nano-particleswith a 1% and 0.5% weight percent on a flat mosaic plate with a diameter of 200 mm heated with a hot air heater. This experiment was performed to determine the absorption and placement of nano-particles on the surface. The nano-particles deposited on the surface even after washing with water jets were not removed. The experiment showed that nano-particle deposition occurs at a temperature of 112 °C and a stable nucleate boiling. But when surfactants are not added to the nano-fluid, absorption of nano-particles does not occur on the surface. BHTC for both non-surfactant and surfactant nano-fluid decreased during boiling. The reason for this is the deposition of particles on the surface,which reduces the solid-liquid contact angle and it increases the critical heatflux. In this study, the sedimentation of nano-particles with surfactants has not been investigated.
The change in the roughness of surface and the active nucleation sites density are among the factors influencing the change in BHTC of
nano-fluid. Since the deposited nano-particles can alter the roughness surface and the active boiling site density, therefore, the properties of the boiling surface substrate change with increasing thickness of the nano-particle sediment over time. On the other hand, after nano-fluid sediment, the surface roughness depends on the roughness and material of the primary surface, concentration of the nano-fluid and the different structure of the nano-fluid prepared. Different surfactants to create a stable nano-fluid create a different nano-fluid structure. Therefore, surface sediment can be different for a variety of surfactants. Surfactants used in this study are classified as anionic (SDS), cationic (CTAB) and non-ionic (PS20). Regarding history, metal nano-fluids, including aluminumoxide, have been extensively investigated. Therefore, the use of silica as themost abundant nonmetallic oxide compound has been limited.Moreover, the sedimentation surface after the boiling process by silica-DI water nano-fluid with the presence of different surfactants has not been studied as one of the parameters affecting surface deposition. In this study, the formation of sediment layers by nanofluid and various surfactants and their effect on boiling heat transfer are assessed. In the following, we study and justify the formation of sediment layers formed on the boiling surface. What is here as a question is whether the sediment layers created by various surfactants after the boiling process affect the boiling heat transfer?
nt with a size of 50 nm in four concentrations of 1, 0.5, 0.1, 0.01% vol.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of nano-fluids
sections.text:
In this study, for preparation of the silica nano-fluid in a water basefluidwith different volumetric percentages at a given diameter, dilution of the initial solution with the pure base (DI water) was used. Eq. (1) was applied to predict the base-fluid needed for the preparation of nano-fluid with a specific volume percentage and the dilution step.
φ1:V1 ¼ φ2:V2 ð1Þ
Where, V1, φ1 are respectively the initial volume of the nano-fluid with the higher concentration and the needed volume of the nanofluid for dilution, and V2, φ2, respectively, are the nano-fluid volume required for use in the test and its volume percentage. In order to provide a nano-fluidwith a specified volumepercentage, the nano-fluid amount has been determined by Eq. (1) and the base-fluid is added to the nanofluid for dilution to reach a certain volume.
To construct the nano-fluid, a specified amount of silica nanoparticles was weighed (about 6.525 g of silica nano-particles for the production of silicon dioxide-DI water nano-fluid with a concentration of 1% volume) and then it was added into a volumetric balloon and 0.163 g of the desired surfactant was added to it. After that, water was added to a volume of 250 ml and then rinsed with a stirrer at a rate of 500 rpm for 180 min. In this research, the surfactants are: sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) and Polysorbate 20 (PS20). Finally, the solution is placed inside the ultrasonic transducer chamber and ultrasound waves were transferred to the solution with a period of 0.5 s and intensity of 60% for 20 min. This waving step was applied to the nanofluid in three steps eventually, each sample was subjected to ultrasound for about an hour. Then, in accordance with Table 1, the nano-fluid was made at different concentrations by diluting the solution attained at this step. In order to make solutions with lower solid volume fractions, a specified amount of solution with initial concentration was taken in accordance with the declared values in the table and then added to the desired base-fluid (DI water). Small volumes
id sample with sodium dodecyl sulfate surfactant with a mean diameter of 48.63 nm.
with the help of micro-pipettes were taken by the laboratory operator and was poured into a 100 ml volumetric balloon.
To make a 0.5% volumetric nano-fluid, at first 75 ml of a nano-fluid sample with 1% volume was taken and by adding the desired basefluid with volumetric balloon it was reached to the volume of 150 ml, in this case, the concentration of silica nano-particles in the nano-fluid sample will be 0.5% vol. As it is stated, water is used to make the nano-fluid and dilute when the base-fluid is water whose construction method is the same as the values given in Table 1.
Silicon dioxide-DI water nano-fluid contains surfactant SDS, CTAB, PS20 at four concentrations of 1, 0.5, 0.1, 0.01% vol. It should be noted that all materials used have been purchased from Merck and Sigma Aldrich. Fig. 1 illustrates the nano-fluid tested with the PS20 surfactant as the sample.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Shape of silicon nano-particles
sections.text:
In this research, the Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) test was used to characterize the geometry and shape of nano-particles. The TEM result was taken in solid state of nano-particles (Company philiphs and Model EM-208). Silica nano-particles used in this study were transferred by adding silica to ethanol nano-particles, after dilution with the amount of about 0.0001% by weight on a perfectly flat graphite plate (with bumps less than 2 nm) to the amount of approximately 0.1 cc. After evaporation of ethanol, the TEM test was performed on the graphite surface. In this test, the nano-particle height was detected by irradiation on the graphite surface. The shape and geometry, and also the diameter of the nano-particles, were determined using low-height (graphite surfaces) and bumps made by nano-particles and the scale of the TEM image of nano-particles (Fig. 2). The shape of the geometry of nano-particles synthesized was almost spherical. These graphs also show well that the size of the silica nano-particles is about 50 nm.
Fig. 6. The results of zeta potential test for nanoparticles of silicon oxide with cet

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Structure of silicon nano-particles
sections.text: Fig. 3 shows the results of the X-RayDiffraction (XRD) test for a sample of silica nano-particles. As shown in this test, a maximum has been shown at the X-ray radiation angle of 25° that, this indicates that silica nano-particles have a completely non-crystalline and with the help of the corresponding equations and XRD test results, estimate the size of crystalline grains in a nano-particle sample. Moreover, comparing this diagramwith the previous reported data, it can be concluded that silica nano-particles are highly purified and can be considered completely with O-Si-O structure [24].

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Size of silicon nano-particles in the base-fluid
sections.text:
One of the ways to measure the diameter of nano-particles in the base-fluid environment is to use the DLS test. In this research, a dynamic light scattering (DLS) test was used to investigate and measure the diameter of silica nano-particles and to provide a nano-particle size distribution curve in base-fluid media used in this research (DI water). The results of these tests for measuring the diameter of the nano-particles for the base nano-fluid sample have been shown in Fig. 4. Because of the fact that, the principles of the dynamic light scattering is by the light source, in order to prevent data deviation from the reality, and also to reduce the measurement error caused by the interference of the size of the nano-particles, in a dynamic light scattering test, a nano-fluid with a concentration of 0.01 Vol% (the most diluted possible mode) was used. Moreover, light dynamic scattering tests were performed for 10 min after nano-fluid samples were prepared by ultrasound on samples (ultrasonic applied to the samples). The results of the light dynamic scattering test for silicon dioxide-water nano-fluid show that, the average diameter of the nano-particles in the base-fluid after the application of the ultrasonic process is about 48.63 nm, which is consistent with the results of the TEM test.
yltrimethyl ammonium bromide surfactant in deionized water as base fluid.

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Results of the stability test of nano-particles or zeta-potential
sections.text: In order to investigate the stability of silica nano-particles in the base-fluid of DI water, and also the lack of particle agglomeration, the surface charge of nano-particles is one of the proper criteria. Because these surface charges are also like, causing electrostatic repulsive force between nano-particles. Surface charges of nano-particles inhibit their inter-connection. Therefore, the more the surface charge of the nanoparticles (more positive or negative) increases the amount of stability or reduces the agglomeration. Zeta-potential test was employed to study the stability of silica nano-particles in base-fluid media. The maximum surface charge of silica nano-particles in all nano-fluids (silica nano-particles with sodium dodecyl sulfate surfactant, cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide or polysorbate 20 in deionized water) is less than −40 mV or more than +40 mV (regarding the nano-particles and basefluid natures, the stability criterion for nano-particles in the fluid medium is that the maximum surface charge are either less than −40 mV or more than +40 mV) [25]. In Figs. 5 to 7, the results of the zeta-potential test for nano-fluids containing silica nano-particles with surfactant, respectively, sodium lauryl sulfate, cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide and polysorbate 20 in the base-fluid of DI water after 30 min of nano-fluid construction and dispersion of nano-particles with ultrasonic apparatus have been presented. The zeta-potential test charts show that silica nano-particles with different surfactants in the base water fluid are very stable. The achieved data of the zetapotential test in Figs. 5, 6 and 7 show that for cases where the silicawater nano-fluids with surfactant of respectively sodium lauryl sulfate, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide and polysorbate 20 have been prepared and the maximum potential surface charge of nano-particles is about −87.4, 74.2 and −97.9 mV and these values are very far from the stability criterion (−40 mV or 40 mV).

sections.heading: 2.2. Experimental device
sections.text:
The device of boiling heat transfer consists of four main sections of the main boiling glass space, the copper cylinder, the electric control unit, and the cooling system. Figs. 8 and 9 display this device.
The main boiling cavity is a clear cylinder of German quartz glass with a high thermal resistance of up to 1600 °C. The internal diameter of this cylindrical glass cavity is 40mm, a length of 350mmand a thickness of 3 mm. The bottom of the glass cylinder is creatively made with edge that the sealing process can be applied to. The glass tube is placed in concentric form with the copper block with a silicone gasket. To produce a one-dimensional heat transfer, a material around the copper should be used, which has a very low heat transfer rate than copper and byplacing it around the copper, theHeatflux is oriented in a vertical upward direction. For this purpose, hollow Italian Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) with a high grade and cylindrical shape with a diameter of 150 mm and a length of 90 mm was used. Thermal conductivity was
0.29 w/m.k, measured by the KD2 Pro device (with the accuracy of 0.01) manufactured by Decagon Corporation. Meanwhile, PTFE is threaded to the outer diameter of copper size as copper is exactly placed inside Teflon. In the Teflon body, two 3 mm holes have been located to accommodate the sensors with a 90° angle (Fig. 10). Copper block is cylindrical made of copper with purity of 96% with a diameter of 40 mm and a length of 90 mm (Fig. 10). The copper thermal conductivity is 401 w/m.K, measured by cussons device, the British model of the P5687. Since the copper thermal conductivity is several times higher than PTFE, the heat transfer rate in the radial direction reaches its lowest value. At the end of the copper cylinder, there are 4 vertical holes 6 mm in diameter and 40 mm in length to position the elements. In copper, there are 4 elements with diameter of 6 mm and length of 4 cm made of stainless steel with a power of 250 watts from the copper end. It should be noted that all elements are fully inserted into the copper block and have no contact with the air. There are also two holes in the body of the copper block at a distance of 15 mm and the other at a distance of 38 mm from the upper surface of the copper cylinder, each of which has a different angle of 90°. These two holes are inserted into the center depth of the copper block (20 mm) to accommodate PT100 sensors. It should be noted that the entire outer surface of copper has a thread that is incorporated into PTFE because of its placement (Fig. 10).
TheResistance Temperature Detectors (RTD) are PT-100 type,with a length of 30 cm. Sensors have been calibrated within the temperature range and have a precision of 0.1 K's degree. Two temperature displays have been used by Autonics Co. and themodel TC4Y. Displays have high performance with a 0.1 error and 4 characters. It also has the ability to
adjust at different temperatures that, using this feature ON-OFF command can be directly applied to the contactor for safety and protection of the device. Meanwhile, the electrical panel has the dimension of 40 × 35 cm. The ammeter and voltmeter are jointly produced byMicromax Company.
Since the measurement and verification of the test requires a constant and uniform heat flux (q”), we need to use the Autotransformer device to keep the voltage and ampere constant. Auto-transformer connected to the Goldstar product is in single phase mode and produces output power from 0 to 300 V. This Auto-transformer is AC and connected directly to the main power grid and its power is manually adjusted. The diameter of the glass compartment is exactly the same as the diameter of the copper block, while due to the brittleness of the glass, too much pressure
cannot be applied because it causes fraction. To remove the restriction and for sealing the device, a holder made of stainless steel with a diameter of 45 mm and 3 holes for PTFE riveting, each of which is at an angle of 120° and the holes continue to the bottom of PTFE, and they are connected with threaded screw clamps is used. It should be mentioned that before linking the glass, silicone gasket has been located on the copper block, then attach the glass and, after connecting the glass chamber, the holder is connected to the screws using a polyurethane washer that, with this gasket, we can put more pressure on the glass to seal and the glass compartment does not lose its resistance. The screw of holder clips have a size of M16 and a length of 10 mm (Fig. 11).
The surface roughnessmeasurements weremade using a roughness meter (SJ210 model) of the Mitutoyo (U.S.A) Company. The usual
opper cylinder.
uncertainty is about 10%. In Fig. 12, the roughness diagram shows that the surface roughness was constant at the start of each experiment andwere determined about 0.319 μm(319 nm). Tomaintain roughness at the beginning of each experiment, the copper surface was polished with a sandpaper of 600, and washed with acetone and DI water to maintain the surface condition in all experiments. The cooling system is applied to keep the fluid level inside the boiling glass container and prevent the evaporation of the fluid inside it. This system is equipped with a glass condenser of 200 mm in length, connected to a glass compartment with a 40 mm diameter polyurethane gasket. Meanwhile, after placing the glass compartment and condenser with a gasket, the special adhesive is used to seal the device physically. The cooling system has a separated unit. The pump inside the cooling vessel includes water and ice when the pump is switched on, cool water is fed through the condenser passing the rotameter and condensates its boiling vapor and then the condensed vapor returns to its boiling cavity and reenters the cooling vessel. In addition, the lower parts of the elements are completely insulated to prevent energy loss by the wool insulation. Meanwhile, the condenser cavity is connected to the atmosphere, and so the pressure of the boiling chamber is the same as the atmosphere pressure of the laboratory. The energy dissipation in theworking conditions is less than 10%.

sections.heading: 2.3. Measurements
sections.text:
If we want to directly measure the boiling surface temperature from the surface, a significant error occurs in computations due to the creation of an additional nucleation site. Therefore, the interpolation method has been used to measure the boiling surface temperature. The two holes in the copper block body are spaced 15 mm and 38 mm apart from the upper surface of copper cylinder with a 120 degree angle (Fig. 13). In each experiment, 150 cc of nano-fluid with different concentrations has been charged in the boiling glass compartment. To keep the heat flux constant and to be sure of the stability conditions, the temperatures were recorded after 10 min ( dT dt ¼ 0:01 K min ).
The space between the heater and heating block is perfectly filled with silicone adhesive (approximately distance between 0.1 mm) with an estimate of the volume (distance) between the heater and
heating block and silicone adhesive and additional adhesive out of space between them we ensure that the space between the heater and thermal block has been filled with adhesive. After using silicon adhesive, the space between the thermal block and surrounding air is completely coveredwith insulating stone adhesive. This will causeminimizing the heat loss. Similarly we used silicone adhesive for holes where there is a thermocouple as before (the space between the heater and heating block) and to ensure the layer of suitable insulating stone adhesive and fiberglass around PTFE. The reason for using silicon adhesive is due to its high thermal conductivity. Also themain application of this adhesive is for computing processors such as CPUs and etc.
According to what was said before, due to copper thermal conductivity is much larger than PTFE, one can ignore the radial heat drop, which means that the heat transfer can be considered one dimensional and in vertical direction. Therefore, the amount of transferred heat flux to its boiling surface, is presented:
q00 ¼ kT2−T1 d2−d1
ð2Þ
After determining the heat flux, using the formula (3), we can determine the difference between the boiling temperature and the saturation temperature.
ΔTS ¼ TS−Tsat ¼ T1−q 00d1 k −Tsat ð3Þ
Therefore, BHTC temperature is calculated in terms of the heat flux and the wall superheat temperature according to Eq. (4):
h ¼ q 00
ΔTS ð4Þ

sections.heading: 3.1. Boiling curve of DI water and repeatability
sections.text:
At the first, the DI water was evaluated three times and compared them with the Rohsenow curve. The empirical equation presented by Rohsenow is as follows: [26–28].
ΔTs ¼ hfg Cp;l Csf q} μ lhfg σ g ρl−ρvð Þ 0:5" #1 3 Prn ð5Þ
Where, hfg is fluid latent heat, ΔTs is temperature difference of surface, σ is surface tension, ρv and ρl are vapor and liquid density, Pr is Prandtl number, and also Csf and n are constants which for the copper surface are 0.013 and 1, respectively. There are few studies in this area which measures the surface temperature in interpolation [29].
As shown in Fig. 14, the experimental results have a very good fit with Rohsenow's empirical correlation. On the other hand, with regard to the importance of repeatability, the experiments were carried out
model device Ra = 0.319 μm.
three times with the same conditions on various days. The findings show that the main characteristics of the boiling heat transfer test are fixed for the other times.
The uncertainty analysis has been performed according to the proposed Moffat method [30] based on Eqs. (6), (7) and (8).
Uq00 q00 ¼ UT2−T1 T2−T1 2 þ Ud2−d1 d2−d1
2 !1=2 ð6Þ
UΔTs ΔTs ¼ UT1−Tsat T1−Tsat 2 þ Ud1 d1 2 þ Uq00 q00
2 !1=2 ð7Þ
Uh h ¼ Uq00 q00 2 þ UΔTs ΔTs
2 !1=2 ð8Þ
Uncertainty for measuring the temperature is 0.1 Kelvin and uncertainty for measuring intervals is 0.1 mm. The results show that the highest uncertainty in calculation of heat flow and BHTC is 6.5% and 8.4%, respectively. Also, the uncertainty of the parameters measured in Table 2 is estimated.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effects of different surfactants at the same concentration
3.2.1. Concentration of 1% vol.
sections.text:
Fig. 15 shows the curve of BHTC in terms of heat flux of silica-DI water nano-fluid with various surfactants at 1% vol. As seen in the figure, BHTC of nano-fluid with SDS and CTAB surfactants for concentration of 1% vol. of nano-fluid (highest concentration) is higher than DI water. Fig. 16 shows the boiling surface before testing (Fig. 16-a), after a nano-fluid boiling test with SDS surfactant (16-b), after pool boiling test of nano-fluid with a CTAB surfactant (Fig. 16-c) and after pool boiling of the nano-fluid with surfactant PS20 (Fig. 16-d). According to Fig. 16-b and c, it is observed that the surface roughness increases with the addition of two surfactants SDS and CTAB due to boiling of the nano-fluid. By increasing the boiling surface roughness, the density of active nucleation sites increases, as a result, increasing the number of bubble separations from the surface increases BHTC. Moreover, BHTC of nano-fluid with surfactant PS20 is lower than DI water. Fig. 16-d shows that the surface sediment due to the boiling of the nano-fluid with the PS20 surfactant increases the thermal resistance of the boiling surface and decreases BHTC. Therefore, the nano-fluid boiling transfer coefficient with the PS20 surfactant will be lower than the boiling transfer coefficient of DI water.
Fig. 13. Arrangement of PT-100 resistive sensors.
Fig. 16-b and c show that the roughness produced at the boiling surface after the boiling heat transfer of the nano-fluidwith the SDS surfactant is greater than that of the CTAB surfactant. Therefore, active nucleation sites for boiling nano-fluid with surfactant SDS larger than CTAB will result in easier separation of bubbles and a nano-fluid boiling transfer coefficient with a SDS surfactant larger than CTAB.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Concentration of 0.5% vol.
sections.text:
Fig. 17 shows the curve of BHTC in terms of the heat flux of silica-DI water nano-fluid with various surfactants at a concentration of 0.5% vol. With regard to the figure, it can be seen that the boiling transfer coefficient of DI water with the SDS surfactant has the highest value that, this is due to the reduction of surface tension caused by the addition of surfactants. Reducing surface tension makes it easier to remove bubbles from the surface, thereby increasing BHTC. Adding surfactant to water, as shown in Fig. 17, increases BHTC. On the other hand, due to this, the increase in nano-fluid may reduce BHTC. So when both the surfactant and the nano-fluid are used, both of these are examined and both are important. If used simultaneously, the effect of surfactant is much greater than the effect of nano-fluid and increases BHTC. On the other hand, using various surfactants (anionic, cationic and nonionic) with different stability, the results of different heat transfer boiling. Therefore, in this study, we investigated the effect of various surfactants (anionic, cationic and non-ionic) on BHTC. The present study was carried out in the region of the nuclear boiling. Therefore, we did not reach the CHF critical heat flux area. According to previous studies, adding nano-fluid to CHF is effective. Fig. 17 also shows that BHTC of nanofluid with SDS and CTAB surfactants for concentration of 0.5% vol. of nano-fluid (like 1% vol. concentration) is higher than DI water. Fig. 18 shows the boiling surfaces before testing (18-a), after a nano-fluid
boiling test with SDS surfactant (Fig. 18-b), after pool boiling of nanofluid with CTAB surfactant (18-c) and after pool boiling of the nanofluid with surfactant PS20 (Fig. 18-d). Fig. 18-b and c show that surface roughness increases with nano-fluid boiling with two surfactants SDS and CTAB. The density of active nucleation sites increases with increasing roughness on its boiling surface, as a result, increasing the number of bubble separations from the surface increases BHTC. Moreover, BHTC of surfactant PS20 nano-fluid is lower than DI water. Fig. 18-d shows that surface deposition due to boiling of nano-fluid with PS20 surfactant increases the thermal resistance of the boiling surface and decreases BHTC. Thus, BHTC of PS20 surfactant nano-fluid is lower than that of the DI water. Due to the nature of surfactants, especially SDS
surfactants, which increase BHTC with reducing surface tension, but in high thermal flux due to surfactant sedimentation and increased surface resistance, BHTC is reduced. Ps20 surfactant is a non-ionic which means it would not help the nano-fluid stability. Moreover Ps20 surfactant shows a very long chain which implies the long chain adheres to the surface.
As indicated for 1% concentration, according to Fig. 18-b and c, the roughness produced at the boiling surface after the boiling heat transfer of the nano-fluid with SDS surfactant will be greater than the CTAB surfactant. Therefore, active nucleation sites for boiling heat transfer for the nano-fluid with surfactant SDS is larger than CTAB, as a result, the separation of the bubbles is easier and BHTC of nano-fluid with the SDS
. Concentration. (a) Copper surface prior to boiling test (b) Copper surface after testingwith TAB (d) Copper surface after testing with nanofluid with PS20 surfactant.
surfactant is larger than the CTAB according to Fig. 17. To investigate BHTC, two roughness factors and boiling thickness are very important. Increasing the amount of roughness will increase the nucleation sites and increase BHTC, but increasing the thickness of the boiling surface will increase the thermal resistance of the boiling surface and reduce BHTC. A quantitative roughness test is one of the best methods for comparing boiling heat transfer. The roughness of the boiling surface ismeasured by the SJ210-model. At all concentrations, the roughness of the boiling surface increases. After the roughness measurements for nanosfluid with surfactant SDS at a concentration of 1%, the roughness value of Ra = 0.435 μm was obtained and in the concentration of 0.01%, the roughness value of Ra = 0.393 μm. Also, by roughening the
nanosilver with CTAB surfactant at a concentration of 1%, the roughness value ofRa=0.404 μmand0.01%of the roughness contentofRa=0.310 μm are obtained. However, as shown in Figs. 16 and 18, at high concentrations (0.5% and 1%), due to the fact that the thickness of the sediment is very high, this results in increased thermal resistance of the boiling surface. Therefore, although surface roughness increases, but in contrast to the surface roughness and thermal resistance for these twosurfactants (SDS and CTAB), while roughness for SDS surfactants is much higher than that for CTAB surfactants, So we expect more heat transfer. However, due to the fact that the thickness of thedeposition increases, this increase in roughness, by increasing the thickness, neutralizes its effect. As a result, we do not see a significant increase in the SDS over the CTAB. However, in lower concentrations, Figs. 19 and 20 (0.01% and 0.1%), SDS surfactants have a lower Roughness than CTAB. Therefore, the lower thermal resistance and more nucleation sites and, as a result, SDS surfactants over CTAB, increase the heat transfer rate.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Concentration of 0.1% vol.
sections.text: Fig. 19 shows the curve of BHTC in terms of heat flux of silica-DI water nano-fluid with different surfactants at a concentration of 0.1% vol. It can be seen that at low concentrations (less than 0.5% vol. of nano-fluid), BHTC of nano-fluid for all surfactants is greater than that of DIwater. It should be noted that sediments on the surface are not observed at low concentrations (less than 0.5% vol. of nano-fluid), therefore, the boiling surface shapes are not used in this section. Reducing surface tensions by different surfactants will make it easier to separate bubbles from the surface, thereby increasing BHTC. As a result, Fig. 19 shows that BHTC of nano-fluids with anionic surfactant is larger than cationic and cationic larger than nonionic, which is also reported in previous studies [31].

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Concentration of 0.01% vol.
sections.text:
Fig. 20 shows the curve of BHTC in terms of heat flux of silica-DI water nano-fluid with different surfactants at a concentration of 0.01% vol. It can be seen that at low concentrations (less than 0.5% vol. of nano-fluid), BHTC of nano-fluid for all surfactants is greater than that of DI water. As previously mentioned, reducing surface tensions by
different surfactants makes it easier to separate bubbles from the surface, and thereby increasing BHTC. Fig. 20 also shows that BHTC of nano-fluids with anionic surfactant (SDS) is greater than cationic surfactant (CTAB) and with cationic surfactant is larger than nonionic surfactant (PS20) that, this result has also been reported in past studies [31]. thickness of the sediment is not observed at low concentrations (0.01% and 0.1%). But there is definitely a deposition that causes roughness and ultimately increases heat transfer to the smooth surface. The depositional figures on the surface of the boiling surface with SDS surfactants with different concentrations are given in the following figure. Therefore, due to the fact that they are visible at low concentrations, its forms have not been reported, this is reported by other authors [29].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, boiling heat transfer of silica-DI water nano-fluid with three anionic, cationic and nonionic surfactants, respectively, SDS, CTAB and PS20 have been experimentally investigated at various concentrations at atmospheric pressure. Nano-fluid has been synthesized by a two-step process and has acceptable stability. The following are the results of this research:
• For concentrations higher than 0.5% vol. of the nano-fluid, the BHTC for the nano-fluid with SDS and CTAB surfactants is greater than the boiling transfer coefficient of the DI water and the boiling transfer coefficient of the PS20 surfactant nano-fluid is lower than the BHTC of the DI water. • For concentrations less than 0.5% vol. of the nano-fluid, the BHTC for the nano-fluid for all surfactants is larger than the BHTC the DI water. • The BHTC of DI water-surfactant for all surfactants is higher than that of DI water. • The use of surfactants in nano-fluids decreases the surface tension; consequently, with the easier separation of bubbles from the boiling surface, the amount of BHTC increases. • The BHTC of DI water-surfactant is higher for all surfactants than for silicon dioxide-DI water–surfactant nano-fluid. • The boiling surface roughness after boiling heat transfer of nano-fluid with the SDS surfactant is higher than the CTAB, hence the heat transfer rate is also higher.
• The boiling surface resistance after boiling heat transfer with the PS20 surfactant is higher than the CTAB, resulting in lower heat transfer rates. • The BHTCof nano-fluids with anionic surfactant (SDS) is greater than cationic (CTAB) and cationic is larger than nonionic (PS20) (SDS N CTABN PS20).
Nomenclature Cp Specific heat (J/Kg.k) Csf Coefficient in Rohsenow correlation d Distance (mm) g Gravity acceleration (m2/s) h Heat transfer coefficient (W/m.k) hfg Fluid's latent heat (J/Kg) k Thermal conductivity (W/m.k) n Power in Rohsenow correlation pr Prandtl number q′′ Heat flux (W/m2) Ra Average roughness of the surface (μm) T Temperature (K) V Volume of the nano-fluid U Results uncertainty
Greek symbols μ Substance dynamic viscosity (N/m2) ρ Substance density (Kg/m3) σ Surface tension (N/m) φ Volume percentage (%vol) ᴓ Diameter (mm)
Subscripts l Liquid s Surface sat Saturated
Abbreviations HTC Heat transfer coefficient BHTC Boiling heat transfer coefficient
